Introduction

Sarcoma botryoides (

figure 1
), an embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, is a rare and aggressive subtype of rhabdomyosarcoma.  It predominantly affects infants and is characterized by a mass with a distinctive grape-like (botryoid) appearance that arises from the genitourinary tract (eg, bladder, vagina).

Pathophysiology and pathology 



Sarcoma botryoides originates from embryonal mesenchymal cells, which are precursor cells that can differentiate into skeletal muscle.  The tumor cells exhibit various stages of muscle differentiation (eg, rhabdomyoblasts).



The hallmark of sarcoma botryoides is its polypoid or grape-like appearance, which is typically seen protruding into a hollow organ (eg, vagina).  Microscopically, the tumor is composed of small, round, undifferentiated cells with eosinophilic-appearing cytoplasm (which occurs due to poorly formed myofilaments).  The presence of a cambium layer, a dense layer of rhabdomyoblasts beneath the epithelium, is a characteristic feature.

Risk factors



Although the exact cause of sarcoma botryoides is not well understood, several risk factors have been identified, including young age (usually age <1) and possible genetic predisposition (eg, Li-Fraumeni syndrome).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of sarcoma botryoides depends on the site of origin:



  • Bladder:  hematuria, urinary obstruction (with possible recurrent urinary tract infections)
  • Vagina:  vaginal bleeding, mucoid vaginal discharge, protruding polypoid-appearing mass

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for sarcoma botryoides is based on the differential diagnosis of prepubertal vaginal bleeding (

) and includes the following:



  • Vaginal foreign body:  can present with mucoid or bloody vaginal discharge, but patients do not have an associated vaginal mass. 
  • Trauma:  can present with bloody vaginal discharge (due to sexual abuse, saddle injury, or abrasion), but patients typically have concomitant bruising and/or perineal trauma (eg, lacerations).
  • Infection:  can present with mucoid or bloody vaginal discharge; in addition, patients with a vulvovaginal infection typically have vulvar and/or perineal erythema.  In patients with sarcoma botryoides of the bladder, a urinary tract infection can be ruled out based on lack of bacteria on urine culture. 
  • Precocious puberty:  can present with vaginal bleeding from early menarche but is rare in infants.  In addition, there are usually additional signs of precocious puberty, including breast and pubic/axillary hair development. 

Diagnosis, laboratory evaluation, and imaging 



Diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical presentation, imaging studies, and histopathological examination.  Physical examination may reveal a mass or protrusion in the vagina or bladder.  Definitive diagnosis is made via biopsy of the mass.  Patients diagnosed with sarcoma botryoides require further evaluation with imaging (eg, CT scan, MRI) to help determine the extent of the tumor and evaluate for metastasis.

Management



Management of sarcoma botryoides involves a multidisciplinary approach, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Prognosis



The prognosis for sarcoma botryoides depends on several factors, including the site of origin, stage of the disease, and response to treatment.  Patients with a favorable prognosis include those with early-stage disease, complete surgical resection, and good response to chemotherapy.  Overall, the survival rate for localized sarcoma botryoides has improved significantly with advances in multimodal therapy, but those with advanced or metastatic disease have poor survival rates.

Summary



Sarcoma botryoides (an embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma) is a rare and aggressive pediatric malignancy that predominantly affects infants.  It is characterized by a mass with a distinctive grape-like (botryoid) appearance that arises from the genitourinary tract (eg, bladder, vagina).
